content: everyone why lock here my wife's
Christmas present to me this year was to move her desk to the other side of the
room so that I could slide my desk over and quadruple my crafting space so I
built a brand new workbench and she suggested I make a video about how I
built it so here it is so we're gonna build a frame from two by fours and then
attach an MDF top MDF medium-density fiberboard comes in three quarter inch
four by eight sheets which are very heavy my home improvement store does
in-store cutting so I had them cut it in half and that's what you see here two
slabs which are two feet wide and 8 feet long having a short wife will help with
the drive home as for lumber two by fours eight feet long first up we're
going to build the skirt now from here on out when I say board I mean a 2x4
also note that a 2x4 isn't actually 2 inches by 4 inches it's one and a half
inches by three and a half inches so cut two boards at ninety three inches and
then two more boards at twenty four inches as illustrated here for all
connections I just used drywall screws no need to pre-drill two by fours are
pretty soft relatively speaking just tack in two of them wherever you join
two boards two screws will ensure two axes of control so that there's no
swiveling next up the legs cut four boards at 30 inches attach them inside
the corners oriented as you see here and here's a picture with three of four legs
attached and here's the whole assembly done and turned over now we just need to
attach a lower skirt so cut one board at ninety three inches and connect two legs
together on the outside then two more boards at twenty four inches attached as
shown so here's my bench turned on its side
note that I've actually used two by sixes from my lower skirt that's just
because I already had some lying around if you use two by four is perfectly fine
so notice two things one there's no board going across the long side for the
front of the lower skirt that's because that's where your chair needs to go and
to the board's on the short ends appear to be one and a half inches too long I
did that because in the future I might wish to add a third leg somewhere in the
middle of the bench and if I do I want to be able to tie it to one of the two
fronts and keep the same aesthetic look the reason I would attach a third leg is
if I wanted to implement a shelf or two so now we just need to attach the MDF
top MDF is not soft you will need to pre-drill the holes get it set in its
final position and then do your pre drills before screwing in I'd recommend
four screws along the front and four along the back space two feet apart for
aesthetics couple quick notes MDF sheets are often manufactured deliberately
larger than listed up to an inch in other words they might not really be 8
by 4 feet they might be ninety seven inches long or forty nine inches wide
all of this instruction assumed a perfect eight by four so either shave
off the excess with your table saw or do what I did and simply adjust your legs
specifically instead of the long boards being 93 inches they might be 94 and the
ends might be 25 inches instead of 24 just measure the MDF board you buy and
adjust it from there also MDF does not like water at all if you spill water on
it immediately begin to soak it up because otherwise it will absorb and
create an ugly bulge so all this was done with only my miter saw and my drill
took about thirty minutes and cost around fifty bucks for all you 3d
printers out there don't forget to check out heroes hoard where you can get true
tiles models as well as a ton of other excellent fantasy related scenery I am
why lock thank you for joining me and I'll see you next time
